values.comments: This course received an extraordinarily positive review; students said Dr. Jordan was a deeply engaging and entertaining lecture. Students especially enjoyed the audio-visual component of the lectures.

Reviews were quite enthusiastic about this course and its professor. Many students felt it was one of the best they have taken at Penn. A few students found the lecture too fast paced and the texts not relevant.
Note: Less than 25% of students submitted written evaluations for this class.

Almost all reviews were quite positive about this course, both the excellent lecturing of r. Messaris and the appeal and interest of the material Some students felt the readings were not directly applicable and other thought the lectures were hard to follow.
Note: Less than 25% of students submitted written evaluations for this class.

Reviewers were very enthusiastic about Dr. Jordan’s teaching and course. Students were especially positive about her willingness to work with students and her ability to stimulate student partcicipation. A few reviewers thought lecture and readings were not related.

section.name: COMM RES W/CHILD & FAM: Comm Research w/Children & Families: Ethical, Theoretical & Method. Issues

values.comments: Reviewers thought this class was excellent and quite informative, and were especially enthusiastic about the guest speakers. Other students thought the class was sometimes repetitive.

section.name: FUT OF NEWS & YOUNG AUD: The Future of News & the Young Audience

values.comments: While the majority of reviews thought the class was interesting and Dr. Meng, an interesting lecturer, some thought the classes could have been more stimulating.

section.name: MEDIA CONTEMPORARY CHINA: Mass Media in Contemporary China

values.comments: Reviewers were extraordinarily positive about this class. Students thought it was well-taught and deeply interesting. Students especially enjoyed the trip to Washington D.C. to visit the Supreme Court.

Reviewers were quite enthusiastic about this course, especially in being available for outside class discussions.
Note: Less than 25% of students submitted written evaluations for this class.

section.name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN COMM: Philosophical Problems of Journalism
COMM RES W/CHILD & FAM: Comm Research w/Children & Families: Ethical, Theoretical, & Method. Issues
LANG SOC CONSTRUCT REAL: Language in the Social Construction of Realities
SP TOPICS IN MASS COMM: PHILOS PROBLMS OF JOURN
SP TOPICS IN MASS COMM: NEW MEDIA & COMM'TY LIFE

values.comments: In general, students found this class to be extremely enjoyable and informative.  Many students expressed their amazement at the depth of material and found Dr. Sender to be extremely good at relating it.  A number of students felt the number of readings was excessive and that group work was ineffective due to the large size of the class.  However, many also enjoyed Dr. Sender’s other innovative teaching methods, such as a heavy reliance on video clips.

Although students generally praised Prof. Turow for his teaching, students were divided on the detail of the material.  While some felt that the course was excellent because of its thoroughness, others found the teaching style boring.  Most students expressed displeasure that the exams tested students on “minute details.”

Students gave this course and Prof. Messaris high praise.  Although many comments lacked substance beyond their general praise for the course, many students noted that this was the best course they have ever taken at Penn.

This course included a lot of work, but a large number of reviewers made the claim that this must be among the best courses taught at Penn.  Students praised Prof. Jamieson for her ability to foster learning, rather than just get through the material.  Many students said that this course required the most work they had ever done for a course, but that it was well worth it.  A few students expressed displeasure over the large number of guest lectures, however.

Students generally enjoyed this class.  A few felt lectures were not very dynamic, and that attendance suffered for it (perhaps also a product of the 9 AM start time).  Many students, however, ranked this course among the best COMM classes they have taken at Penn.

Students generally felt that Professor Jackson did a very good job with this class, with many students noting he worked to make sure students really understood the material and developed useful thinking skills.

Students enjoyed the course, but many left suggestions for the professor.  Some students felt the final project was too technical and production-oriented and that more time was needed to complete it.  Other students felt the 3-hour lectures dragged on and could have used more dynamic teaching methods to keep students alert.  Overall, however, students expressed praise for Prof. Linebarger.

section.name: Communication Law, Policy, and Public Interest
The Internet & Chinese Society: Technology, Power, and Democracy
SPECIAL TOPICS IN COMM: RITUAL COMMUNICATION
SPECIAL TOPICS IN COMM: MEDIA & THE MAYORAL RACE
Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Representation in Popular Media

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to the fundamentals of communication behavior. It focuses on social science studies relating to the processes and effects of mass communication. Research reviewed includes media use behavior and media influences on knowledge, perceptions of social reality, aggressive behavior, and political behavior.   

Students described this course as \"very interesting\" and \"great.\" It was \"engaging,\" \"entertaining,\" and \"valuable.\" However, students criticized its quick pace, noting that it was difficult to take notes because of the lack of visual aids.

Students \"loved\" Professor Hardy. They thought that he was \"wonderful\" and \"interesting.\" Some complained, though, that he was often hard to keep up with and should use a slide show to make note-taking easier.

Many students bemoaned the numerous and lengthy readings, also noting that the details of those readings should be better reviewed in class. The course was recommended, even to non-majors. This course fulfills the Society sector.

section.name: VALUES IN TECHNOLOGY: TECHNOLOGY, SOCIETY, LAW, VALUES, AND DESIGN
Feature-Length Motion Picture Production Laboratory I

values.comments:
Public space is a comprehensive context for human interaction and communication at all scales – from great moments in history to subtle and routine daily events. It is the intersection of the individual life and the communal life, where societies express their character. Public space is the physical medium that we all share. It is a rich environment that gives relevance to our common understanding and to our memory of what takes place and what we say to each other - a physical reference for the action of life. This course will survey and discuss the scope of public space, with the objective of finding its definition

Overall, students felt that the course was interesting and liked that it offered something different from the other communications courses. One student called it “an introduction to a new way of thinking” and another liked that it “crossed into many areas of study like art history and psychology” and “challenged you to think outside the box.” While most people saw the slightly different perspective as a benefit, some thought that it focused too much on urban studies instead of communication.

Professor Kelley was considered by some to be "opinionated" and spent too much of the lecture time talking rather than having class discussions. Other however felt he "kept the class interesting" and was very intelligent and thoughtful with “an excellent attitude and good goals for the class.”

Students felt that the amount of work was overwhelming at times and the journal was hard to keep up with. You need to watch movies, go downtown, do papers and keep a journal for the course.

section.name: Chinese Media, Advertising and Consumer Culture

values.comments:
This course is designed to explore the unique issues that arise for communications researchers who work with children. The class begins by considering the role of theory in designing research, then reviews the major methodological approaches, and finally examines the variety of contexts in which such research is employed.
The course considers the unique ethical issues and protective mechanisms in place. The course culminates in group-based, supervised research wherein students have an opportunity to design and implement a child-focused study.    Students reported that the course was one of “the most useful and well-taught” they had taken at Penn. Although it “was a good course overall”, some students reported difficulty having no prior research class experience.  
While students seemed to like each professor, individually one said the co-taught class “hindered my learning experience …[there were] too may conflicting style of teaching” and several others said the class was unorganized. However one student wrote, “I especially enjoyed the balance between [the two] personalities, [they] definitely complement each other as instructors” Another student reported “Amy Jordan is one of my favorite teachers…I think I could have done much better had it been only her teaching.”
Students said the exams were hard with one student mentioning that material they were tested on was “too trivial.” The course culminated in a final project which included a significant time of prep-work and execution time, reported by several students in the class.

section.name: The Politics of Muslim Immigration in Europe

values.comments:
This course focuses on the modern media and its impact on government and politics. It primarily covers the post-Watergate/post-Vietnam era of journalism, the past quarter century. It focuses each week on specific topics and areas of post-Watergate journalism. In weeks when there are not guest lecturers, the first half of class concerns the assigned readings and the second half of class talks about current press coverage of national events over the prior week. In addition to assigned readings, students are required to stay informed about major national news stories and to follow coverage of them in the national media outlets. An important objective of this course is to afford students the opportunity to interact and discuss the intersection of the press, politics and public policy with some of the leading practitioners in the field, people who work in the \"media environment\" created by the national press.

Students found the class “absolutely wonderful.” The numerous “terrific guest speakers” helped to flesh out the topics of the class. Many students spoke highly of the trip to Washington with its accompanying speakers and experiences. A number of students called the course the “best,” or “one of the best,” they have taken at Penn.

Professor Hunt was universally loved by his students. One student called him “one of the kindest and smartest [professors] I have had the privilege of having” at Penn. Another student praised him for not only building a relationship between him and the students but between the students themselves. The only complaint, articulated by one student, was that he might have provided more guidance on the final paper topic.

The difficulty and amount of work required by this course was relatively low. It was strongly recommended to both majors and non-majors.

section.name: COMM &EMERGENCY RESPONSE: COMMMUNICATIONS AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE
JOURNALISM & PUBLIC SERV: JOURNALISM & PUBLIC SERVICE
FACING RACE: RACE AND CARICATURE IN THE HISTORICAL IMAGINATION
INTIMACY, PRIVACY & SURV: Intimacy, Privacy & Surveillance
TOPICS FILM HISTORY: Internet Policy and Culture
Introduction to Mass Media and Society
Communications, Policy , Advocacy, and Media Market Structure
NEW TECH, COMM & CONTROL: New Technology, Communication, and Control
Communication Law, Policy, and Public Interest
COMM POL, ADV, & MEDIA: COMMUNICATIONS POLICY, ADVOCACY, AND MEDIA MARKET STRUCTURE
SPECIAL TOPICS IN COMM: CHILDREN'S MEDIA POLICY
Communication Law, Policy, and Public Interest
Race Films:  Spike Lee and his Interlocutors
Race Films:  Spike Lee and his Interlocutors
Chinese & US Perspectives on Intellectual Property, Piracy & Creativity

values.comments:
Introduction to Communication Behavior is an intro level course that fulfills a requirement for admission to the communications major. It can also be counted as a society sector requirement for the College. The course focuses on social science studies relating to the processes and effects of mass communication. Students review research on the ways media affects knowledge, perceptions of social reality, aggressive behavior, and political behavior. 

While this survey course lacks the depth some students hoped for, almost all felt it was an important course for communication majors to take. 

Professor Chomsky was praised as a “stimulating,” “knowledgeable,” and “dedicated” teacher, who was always willing to help.  Several students commented that Professor Chomsky was too repetitive and difficult to follow as he often went on tangents.  Almost all students complained that the instructor did not use slides or Powerpoint presentations, which made the lecture material more difficult to process. 

Students mentioned that it was not too difficult to make a good grade if they attended lectures regularly and did the reading, especially since “there are no trick questions on the tests.”  This course is a requirement for all Communication majors.

This course examines the influence of public health communication on health behavior. The course will consider: intervention programs addressing behaviors related to cancer, cardiovascular disease, HIV/AIDS, drug use, obesity and others; theories of health behavior change; issues in the design of effective health communication programs; concerns about the portrayal of health and medicine on mass media.

Overall, students enjoyed the course and one commented that it was “the best I’ve had at Penn.”  Multiple students commented that they enjoyed attending lecture and were always engaged in discussions.

Students described Professor Jacobsohn as “knowledgeable,” “encouraging,” and “approachable.”  Multiple students commented that she “truly cares about her students” and tailored the class to students’ interests.  Students praised the instructor for her ability to communicate subject matter clearly while keeping students interested, relaxed, and involved.

Students highly recommend the course to others.  They commented that Professor Jacobsohn assigned a manageable amount of work, was realistic in her expectations of the students, and graded fairly.

This course explores the historical and contemporary role of the advertising industry in the U.S. media system. Readings included social histories of advertising, economic examinations of advertising\'s role in society, and critical analyses of the ad industry\'s power over the media. The course relied on readings from multiple sources, but students especially enjoyed the “wonderful” primary textbook “Advertising and Culture: Theoretical Perspectives” by Mary Cross. 

Students reported strong positive impressions of the class material. Most of them characterized it as relevant, easily understandable, yet edifying at the same time. “This course opened my eyes to much of the world of advertising,” one student wrote.  The course required extensive reading (some complained it was too much) for each class. Graded assignments for the course were two exams and one paper.

In general, students enjoyed coming to Professor Turow’s lectures, pointing out his “nerdy” in-class jokes, the fact that his lecture material was up-to-date, and his enthusiasm for the subject matter, as ample reason to come to class. 

Students characterized the course as particularly worthwhile for anyone already interested in advertising, “otherwise, you may hate it.”  Freshmen may wish to consider taking lower-level Communications courses before taking this one: “As a freshman, I felt challenged in this course. The material was dense, seeing as this wasn’t an introductory course, but I still learned a lot and felt taking a prior Comm class would have helped me.”  Students strongly criticized Professor Turow’s tests. “I really enjoy the class, and understand the material,” one student wrote, “However, the exams seem to trick you, and test you on specific random sections rather than broad theories discussed in class.” Many students echoed this sentiment, using words like “harsh” and “unfair” to characterize the grading of the exams. Some students were also concerned about the standard lecture format, as well as the amount of reading required for the course.

section.name: LOCAL NEWS MEDIA & URBN: Local News Media and Urban Policy
SPECIAL TOPICS IN COMM: Journalism and Public Service
SPECIAL TOPICS IN COMM: RITUAL COMMUNICATION
RACE: HIST, THEORY& PRAC: RACE: HISTORY, THEORY & PRACTICE
COVERING THE MIDDLE EAST: Reporting on the Middle East: Challenge of World's most Controversial Beat

values.comments: This course is an introduction to the fundamentals of communication behavior. It focuses on social science studies relating to the processes and effects of mass communication. Research reviewed includes media use behavior and media influences on knowledge, perceptions of social reality, aggressive behavior, and political behavior.     Students generally felt that while this course covered the basics of communication well and was a “necessary” course, it was not a particularly engaging one. Several students described the course as “dull” and with “the potential to be much more interesting.” Many students commented that the course only covered the “basics” and “oversimplified” complex theories. A few students commented on the redundancy of the information covered in the readings, lectures, and recitations, causing some students to feel that attendance was “unnecessary.” One student reported that the course material itself was “interesting” and allowed them to “learn a lot about mass media,” and another noted that it provided a “nice overview for a lot of communications-related topics.” Recitations were reported to be more enjoyable than lectures. The course includes a midterm, final exam, and a paper.  Students had mixed opinions about Professor Moehler. While one student described her as “enthusiastic and engaging,” others faulted her for creating the dullness that characterized the course in most students’ opinions. One student reported that Professor Moehler could have made the class “more engaging and relatable to [students’] everyday lives.” Professor Moehler used lecture slides that she also posted online.    Students generally agreed that this introductory course was a good way to learn the basics of communications and a particularly “helpful” foundation for freshmen planning to major in communications. This course fulfills the Society sector and is a requirement for the Communications major. Upperclassmen who took the course described it as easy. Students reported that the course “held students’ hands the entire way” and “spoon-fed” everything to them. While some students felt that the course was “fair” and described class expectations and goals as “clearly outlined,” several other students were frustrated by what they felt was a discrepancy between the oversimplification of the lectures and paper and the difficulty of the exam. One student described the exam as “astronomically harder” than the readings and information discussed, and another agreed that what was learned in class had to be “stretched for the exam.” However, nearly all students agreed that the paper was “pretty straightforward.” One student noted that a “helpful” study guide was provided for both the midterm and final. Readings for this course were described by one student as “typically very long.”

This course focuses on the workings of American mass media as an integral part of American society. The course focuses around questions such as how might we think about the legal, political, economic, historical, and "cultural" considerations that shape what we watch on TV, read in books, and stare at in billboards and what ideas are relevant for examining the enormous changes in the mass media system and the consequences of those changes?   Students felt that this course was “very informational”. However, most students felt that exams focused on minute details and specifics of the reading, rather than on the over-arching concepts. Students claimed that class lectures were “one-sided” and repeated the information and perspective of the assigned reading.   Students’ opinions of Professor Turow were sharply divided. Some heaped praise of him and wrote that his teaching style was “interesting” and “engaging”. Some students reported that Professor Turow was inaccessible outside of class and encouraged students to meet with their TA’s instead.  Many wrote that averages on exams were unexpectedly low. This course may be used to satisfy the Society Sector requirement.

This course offers an interesting look inside the relationship between race and the how it is portrayed in the media. Thus, the course looks at how race is constructed through the media as a sociopolitical concept and how race affects or reflects social attitudes. The class is intended to study these two concepts from various angles so students are able to understand them in multiple ways.   Students found this course to be “excellent.” In general, the material was described as interesting and the course itself gave students a medium of learning and discussing a hot issue. At times the material could be presented in solely abstract ways, which sometimes lessened interest and confused students.   Professor Berger was liked but sometimes described as boring. Though one could tell that he had an interest in the matter, some students said he often struggled to inspire interest in others. Students agreed that he was kind and genuine. Overall, he was praised for being understanding of his students.   This course was neither described as easy nor hard but the required readings that were often said to be dense and “a bit much,” although it was all relevant to the course. Often students had trouble incorporating these theoretical readings into class discussions and consequently they turned out a little flat. Overall the course was well liked by the students.

section.name: Race and Media in 20th Century U.S. History

values.comments: This course examines the history of childhood and play. The course begins with an exploration of the stages of childhood and how rearing, schooling, and relationships influence children. The second half of the course examines the theories, culture, and artifacts of playtime. Students attend lectures, participate in group discussions, read book chapters and journal articles, examine children’s artwork and writing samples, observe children at play, and examine representations of childhood in popular culture.   Students were generally favorable towards the materials and topics covered in class. Most readings were “enjoyable and informative.” Several students noted a divergence between lectures and readings. Some students argued that a large portion of the reading assigned for the course was not discussed.  Students generally praised Professor Linebarger for an engaging teaching style. Professor Linebarger’s incorporation of, “her own relevant family stories” helped keep the material refreshing. Students described Professor Linebarger as “entertaining and funny,” while also assuring that the professor was “always available for students.”   Reaction to this course was generally favorable. One student claimed that, “I would recommend this course for both majors and non-majors.” Several students cautioned, however, that the exams were more difficult than expected. Students expressed anxiety that, “the exam was very specific” and that, “it was somewhat difficult to know what was important to study.” While many students noted how much reading was assigned for the course, students found Professor Linebarger to be, “very fair in grading” and, “flexible with cutting readings and extending deadlines.”

This course examines children's relationship to media in its historic, economic, political and social contexts. The class begins with an exploration of the ways in which "childhood" is created and understood as a time of life that is qualitatively unique and socially constructed over time. It continues with a review of various theories of child development as they inform children's relationship with and understanding of television and other household media. The course teaches students how to make a critical examination of research on the impact of media on children's physical, cognitive, social and psychological development.   Students enjoyed taking this class and considered the course material as "incredibly interesting."   There seemed to be a general consensus that Professor Jordan was an engaging and exceptional teacher. One student said, " Dr. Jordan is an excellent professor. Her lectures are very clear and informative." Others used words such as, "brilliant" and, “charismatic” to describe Professor Jordan.   The class is defined as, "organized and structured," and the professor promotes discussion. This class fulfills a Society requirement. It is open to both freshmen and upperclassmen.

The course discusses theory, research, and application in the persuasive effects of communication in social and mass contexts. Primary focus of the class covers the effects of messages on attitudes, opinions, values, and behaviors. Applications include political, commercial, and public service advertising; propaganda; and communication campaigns.   Students found the course material “interesting” and “useful.” Many said that it “had potential,” but was overshadowed by the general disorganization of the class.   Reviews of Professor Simons were in some cases negative. Several students claimed that he was “not a very engaging lecturer,” “never stuck to the syllabus,” and was constantly revising due dates.  This course does not fulfill any general requirements. There are no prerequistis listed for this course. It is open to both freshmen and upperclassmen.

Contemporary Politics, Policy and Journalism is a course on the modern media and its impact on government and politics. It focuses on the post-Watergate/post-Vietnam era of journalism, the past quarter century.     An important objective of this course is to afford students the opportunity to interact and discuss the intersection of the press, politics and public policy with some of the leading practitioners in the field, people who work in the "media environment" created by the national press. There are 3 papers in the whole course.    Professor Hunt is described as “extremely knowledgeable” and the course as a whole can be described as one word – “incredible”. Students though the guest speakers were “excellent”. Students also have respected comments for Professor Hunt as he is a man with great stories from the journalism world. Professor Hunt takes the class on trips to DC and dinner throughout the semester.     In addition to assigned readings, students are required to stay informed about major national news stories and to follow coverage of them in the national media outlets. The materials read were mostly for own fulfillment rather than for class discussions. This course might feel redundant if this is not the first communications course.

This course seeks to trace the evolving relationship between new media and the political process from three perspectives: the voter, political campaigns and candidates, and the news media. The course begins with a broad overview of the main theories of political communication and U.S. political campaigns leading up to 1996, the year the internet debuted in a presidential campaign. It will then follow this evolution from the 1996 presidential campaign through the 2010 midterm campaigns and suggest implications going into the 2012 campaign. In addition, the course will examine issues of new media and activism, governance and transparency. Students highly praised this course and said that they learned a lot. Some of the highlights include great guest speakers and a useful class Facebook group that stimulated many class discussions.    Professor Winneg also received great reviews. As one student wrote “[Professor Winneg] understands and appreciates his students”. Another described him as “fair” and “flexible”. Even though his lectures can sometimes be “dry”, Professor Winneg overall received high marks with students.    This course is recommended to majors. Anyone interested in a career in media or communications should consider taking this course.

This course provides an overview of recent research on the social implications of new information and communication technologies. The goal of this course is to focus on how recent technological innovations, including personal computing, video games, the Internet and mobile phones may be changing the way we interact with those around us.   Almost every student that wrote a review seemed to enjoy the course. One student wrote that the course was, a very interesting course dealing with very relevant and current material.” The only complaint of the course was that students, “don’t like being forced to write about weekly readings.”  Most students wrote praise of Professor Hampton. Students felt that, “Professor Hampton is engaging and funny.” Some students felt that Professor Hampton could have tried to find conclusions to class conversations.  This course is an upper level course. It has two prerequisites, which are listed as, COMM 125 or COMM 130. It is not listed as fulfilling any requirements.

This seminar focuses on the music video genre to explore topical and conceptual the heart of the globalization of the media and cultural industries. After a formative period largely grounded in North America and Western Europe, the music video migrated to other parts of the world in the 1990s as a wave of privatization and liberalization engulfed national media systems worldwide. Based on a variety of scholarly and trade readings about the globalization of media and culture, the changing media and creative industries, and the music video genre itself, questions to be tackled include: What changes when a media form migrates from its original context? What does the content of music videos reveal about socio-economic and cultural change worldwide? How do music videos rearticulate gender and sexuality, and nationalism? What transnational circuits of ideas, images and ideologies are enabled or constrained by music video?   Students loved this course and found the material extremely interesting. One student noted that the subject was interesting because it made you look at an entertaining product in an “analytical” way.   Professor Kraidy was described as knowledgeable, “insightful”, and “enthusiastic”.   This review was written based on fewer than 8 student comments.

section.name: TPCS IN AFRICANA STUDIES: The Black Body and the Lens
The Media and Communications Industries in Global Perspective
Freaks and Geeks: People on Display

values.comments:
This course will focus upon and examine the ethics of international heritage, the ethics of international heritage, and the role that museums play in the preservation of identity and cultural heritage. The mission of this course will be to inform and educate students about the role of museums within the 21st century. What is the role and position of antiquities and important cultural objects in museums? How should museums acquire these objects and when should they be returned to countries and cultural groups? Examples from current issues will be included in the reading and discussions along with objects and issues within Penn Museum.

Despite having a significant amount of work assigned, students seemed to sincerely enjoy the course. One student said, "The course really opened me up to the variety of topics regarding museums, cultural heritage, and public policy." Students used words like "practical" and "interesting" to describe the course.

Students by and large enjoyed having Professor Leventhal. One student said, "Professor Leventhal is a very cool person with interesting ideas. I like that he was interested in the students' ideas and analysis, not just lecturing [...] I feel lucky to have had the opportunity to take a class with him." Other students used words like "interesting" and "interactive" to describe Professor Leventhal.

This class is recommended to both non-majors and majors. There is a lot of reading, but it is said to be manageable. Reportedly, not all of the assigned readings are gone over in lecture. There is a good amount of writing required, but no exams. There are no prerequisites.

section.name: TELEVISION AND MEDIA: Reality and Documentary Television

values.comments:
Communications 123 considers the critique of popular culture as mere trivia and "just entertainment;" it has been condemned as propaganda, a tool of mass deception; and its consumers have been dubbed fashion victims and couch potatoes. It also examines evaluations that suggest that popular culture offers valuable material for the study of social life. This course will consider the meanings and impact of popular culture, including its effects on how we see ourselves, others, and American life; who makes distinctions between high, middlebrow, and low or mass culture; and how power and resistance structure the production and consumption of popular texts.

Most students really enjoyed this “interesting, entertaining, and thought-provoking” class. Considered by many to be one of the best classes they have taken at Penn, students still claimed that the workload for this course was “a bit much for an introductory Communications course” and that the grading on the tests and papers was “harsh.” Overall, students found the readings and lectures “extremely engaging” and claimed that they were “never bored.”

Professor Paxton was viewed by her students as “exciting,” for she “frequently had the class in laughter.” She was able to keep students awake and present in class because the material and the way it was presented was “educationally stimulating, while still being entertaining.” Most students also commented on Professor Paxton’s approachability or willingness to help them with the material on her own time. It was noted, however, that she is “demanding of her students” and “expects a lot.”

This course is recommended for students interested in pop culture or communications, but is “challenging for an introductory course.” Many students felt that they had to work hard to get an A in this class and that the grading was purposefully difficult. With two papers, three tests, and many readings, students often felt overwhelmed with work that ultimately didn’t pay off due to the harsh grading. However, students commented that they generally “enjoyed the readings” and the “curve for the course helped.”

section.name: Black Cultural Studies: Histories, Theories, Methods and Critique

values.comments:
Communications 225 focuses on children's relationship to media throughout history.  The class has four aims. First, it explores how the notion of childhood was formed. Second, it examines different explanations of child development and the role of media. Third, it studies economic forces and public policies. Finally, it explores research concerning the effects of media on children. 

Overall, students found this course very engaging. The amount of work, however, discouraged some. Some students felt that the final exam and term paper were scheduled too close together.  Others thought the term paper was overly long. Overall though, students enjoyed the material.

Students heap praises on Professor Jordan. One student described her as “friendly and accessible,” while another said her lectures were “fun, relevant, and engaging.” There were no negative comments about Professor Jordan.

This class caters towards Communications majors and minors. Students described the course as “fun,” but “challenging” and “time-consuming.” Generally, students considered the weekly homework light, but the big assignments significant. There is a comprehensive final, as well as a term paper.

*Communications 341 takes a philosophical, historical, and practical approach to understanding why and how the US media industries are regulated. It begins by examining the philosophical tension regarding free speech rights vs. child protection obligations and the media effects beliefs that would drive media regulation. Next, it examines the process of media policy formation and implementation, including the role of regulatory agencies, industry lobbyists, academic researchers and child advocates in advancing distinct policy agendas. Throughout the course a range of policy actions, from legislatively required parental monitoring tools (such as the V-Chip) to voluntary industry efforts (such as network restriction of junk food advertising) are surveyed. Evidence of the success of these efforts in limiting children's exposure to damaging content and in improving parents' ability to supervise their children's media use is considered. 

Students enjoyed that the course structure was based on both lectures and student-led discussions. This allowed everyone to voice their opinions and have more open discussions. Students liked that the class was “relevant to current events.”

A huge majority of the students raved about Professor Jordan. One student claimed that Professor Jordan was “a great instructor, fair, and incredibly nice.” This opinion was widely held, as many students claimed Professor Jordan was their favorite teacher at Penn. They praised Professor Jordan’s ability to make the subject matter very interesting. 

This class comes recommended to all. Both the content and the professor were highly regarded as being both exceptionally interesting and very fair. 

*This review is based on only 8 student comments

Communications 413 endeavors to explore the myriad uses of public opinion in leadership and decision-making. Students will examine what public opinion research is, how it is conducted, and how it is subsequently utilized in a wide range of contexts, both public and private. The course use numerous actual case studies involving public opinion in political campaigns, constituency organizing, crisis management, and a variety of other contexts to provide an inside view of how opinion research is actually conducted and used.  

Overall, students were incredibly pleased with this course, describing it as "absolutely amazing," "so interesting," and "always intriguing." Students reported learning much from the course and felt it offered "real life skills" and "great preparation for the real world."

Students praised Professor Hart as "great," "enthusiastic," and "incredibly knowledgeable."  Many students reported loving Professor's Hart's lectures. They thought he was great at conveying the course material.

This course is for majors only. Some students reported that the course was "a lot of work," but many agreed that Professor Hart assigned "excellent readings." One student pointed out that most of the coursework is assigned for the final weeks of the semester. In addition, the class did a group presentation, which one student described as "very fun."

section.name: AMRCAN INDNS &THE MEDIA: American Indians and the Media

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to the fundamentals of communication behavior. It focuses on social science studies related to the processes and effects of mass communication. Research reviewed includes media usage behavior and media influences on knowledge, perceptions of social reality, aggressive behavior, and political behavior.
Students found that this class moved too quickly and covered far too much material. They believed that lectures were disorganized and had difficulty taking notes. Students also complained that the lectures were not made available to them online. However, they enjoyed recitations and thought the TAs were very effective. 
Opinions about Professor Moehler were mixed. Some students said that she was an effective lecturer, while others thought that she spent too much time reading off of the slides. She was not a very accessible professor. 
This class is recommended for majors. Students found the workload reasonable but found the examinations very challenging.

By acquainting students with the workings of American mass media as an integral part of American society, the aim of this course is to begin to consider how we might think about the legal, political, economic, historical, and “cultural” consideration that shape what we watch on TV, read in books, and stare at in billboards. The course discusses what ideas are relevant for examining the enormous changes in the mass media system and the consequences of those changes.
Students remarked that the subject matter was interesting. However, most complained that the lecture slides were “overwhelmingly dense” and could have benefited from multimedia examples of the topics being discussed. Despite the class being heavily based on textbook material, students found it difficult to prepare for the exams particularly because lecture notes were not posted online and the grading system was slightly harsh.
Though Prof. Felsenthal was described by students as “nice,” the majority of the class found his teaching style to be rather lackluster. However, many students agreed that the “TA presentations and guest lecturers were interesting, informative, and were relevant to current events.”
Students warn that the lectures were fast-paced and suggest bringing a laptop to class. This course fulfills a Communications major requirement as well as the Society Sector.

This course is designed to explore the history and construction of childhood and investigate the importance of play. To that end, during the first part of the course we will explore the idea of childhood including infancy, middle childhood, and the invention of adolescence; changing notions of child-rearing (e.g., “experts”, discipline, place in society); schooling; vulnerable children; the child and the state; and the child’s world (e.g., relationships with parents and peers; consumer culture; media; play). During the second part of the course, we will explore play in more detail including the culture of play; theories of play; artifacts used in play; and ways to study play. Course activities include lectures and group discussions; reading book chapters and empirical journal articles; examining children’s artwork and writing samples; observing children at play; exploring children’s artifacts (e.g., video games, board games, toys, videos, TV shows, books); and examining representations of childhood in popular culture. There will be several small writing projects (i.e., 3-5 pages); a mid-term and final (i.e., multiple choice, short-answer, and essay questions); and a final project designed in consultation with the instructor and/or TA.
A number of students felt that the course was not accurately represented by the title and that it should be listed in the Psychology department rather than the Communications department. That said, many described the material as “interesting and fun.”
Reviews of Professor Linenbarger’s style were mixed. Some students really enjoyed being able to have such a great deal of discussion and sharing of personal experience despite the 90-person class size. Most found this to be frustrating, however, with students complaining that all the discussion was “not really necessary, particularly since there were many times when the professor could not finish the lecture.” Furthermore, students agreed that Professor Linenbarger’s tardiness led to an overall decrease in class productivity. Nevertheless, they conceded that Professor Linenbarger “knows how to engage a class and encourage participation.”
Students found the workload to be manageable but noted that since so much class time is devoted to discussion, exams tend to test material that was only covered in the reading. Students found that the papers were “not very taxing” and somewhat unique.

This course examines theory, research, and application in the persuasive effects of communication in social and mass contexts. The primary focus is on the effects of messages on attitudes, opinions, values, and behaviors. The applications include political, commercial, and public service advertising, propaganda, and communication campaigns (e.g. anti-smoking).
While some students claimed the course was very interesting, others found the material somewhat dry. They found lectures to be disorganized and thought that the readings were poorly organized as well. Many students complained about the TAs.
While some students found him to be engaging, others thought Professor Cappella could have been more effective in conveying the ideas in the lectures. 
This class is highly recommended for majors. There were mixed opinions on the amount of work required for the class. Though some students claimed the work was excessive for the class, others thought it was very reasonable and enjoyable. One student really enjoyed the project, claiming it helped him “to acquire knowledge and skills [directly]."

section.name: Chinese Media, Advertising and Consumer Culture
JOURNALISM & PUBLIC SERV: JOURNALISM & PUBLIC SERVICE

values.comments:
This course offers students the opportunity to explore the relationship between the media industry and the public and the role groups and movements can play in holding the media accountable to serve the public interest. We will wrestle with what that responsibility looks like by engaging the following questions: What obligations do media outlets have to offer fair, accurate, unbiased and inclusive representations in news and entertainment? How do media "insiders" understand this responsibility? Is it clear when a talk show host "crosses the line?" How do we define balance? Are there really two sides to every issue? What is media advocacy? What does it look like? What are the strategies and tactics employed by media activists? How do media insiders effectively contend with media outsiders lobbying for change? These questions will be explored in historically contextualized ways, using a diverse menu of social and political movements and examining the issues with recourse to all sides of the political spectrum.
Students heaped praise upon this course, with a number of students claiming it was “the best class [they] have taken at Penn.” Students found the course to be very “hands-on,” and described assignments as relevant and applicable. Students stressed on the uniqueness of the course, commenting that it “explored a sector of communications that is rarely touched upon in other classes within the department,” and that it gave them something that “no other course offered.”
Students had almost exclusively positive things to say about Professor Garry, describing her as “influential,” “engaging,” and “distinguished.” A minority of students found that Professor Garry espoused her own views and was not always objective. Students agreed that Professor Garry is “always willing to meet with her students and thrives in a classroom setting.”
Those students who took the course found it to be very practical and applicable “to social media, media advocacy, and non-profits.”

section.name: INTIMACY, PRIVACY & SURV: Intimacy, Privacy & Surveillance
STUDIO CONTEMP BLK WOMEN:  Studio in Contemporary Black Women Artists
The Speaking Body and the Marks of the Mind in Modern Western Culture

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to the fundamentals of communication behavior. It focuses on social science studies relating to the processes and effects of mass communication.  Research reviewed includes media use behavior and media influences on knowledge, perceptions of social reality, aggressive behavior, and political behavior. 
A majority of students felt this was an interesting course that provided insight into some “exciting” communications, topics, but did not stimulate their interest as much as they thought it would. Students seemed to enjoy the coursework and material, but in general did not hold strong feelings regarding the course content. 
About half of the students thought Professor Ben-Porath could present the material in an “engaging manner” but the other half found him very “dull and boring.” Overall, most students noted that the TAs were very helpful and that Professor Ben-Porath was very willing to help his students.
Students recommended this course for everybody with an interest in communications, but stated that students should be prepared to attend the lecture if they wish to do well.

section.name: HEALTH COMM DIGITAL AGE: Health Communication in the Digital Age

values.comments:
This course examines children's relationship to media in its historic, economic, political and social contexts. The class explores the ways in which "childhood" is created and understood as a time of life that is qualitatively unique and socially constructed over time. It continues with a review of various theories of child development as they inform children's relationship with and understanding of television and other household media. It next reviews public policies designed to empower parents and limit children's exposure to potentially problematic media content and simultaneously considers the economic forces that shape what children see and buy. The course concludes with a critical examination of research on the impact of media on children's physical, cognitive, social and psychological development.
	Students very much enjoyed this course: it was described as a “wonderful course” and “amazing.” The material covered was “relevant and applicable” and was also described as “really interesting.” The exams were described as “very fair.”
	Professor Jordan was universally praised by her students, who found her to be “brilliant, kind and accessible” as well as “understanding and clear” and a “terrific lecturer.” She was lauded for encouraging “students to participate by asking questions and by facilitating discussion.” 
	This course was praised by all students who commented: not one negative comment was made. Professor Jordan received great reviews, and the course material was described as both interesting and “worth it.”

This course covers the theory, research and application in the persuasive effects of communication in social and mass contexts. Primary focus is on the effects of messages on attitudes, opinions, values, and behaviors.  Applications include political, commercial, and public service advertising; propaganda; and communication campaigns (e.g. anti-smoking).
	Students enjoyed the "great material" in this course and many students felt they learned a lot of "applicable knowledge."
	Many students praised Professor Cappella as a "knowledgeable" and "fantastic" lecturer.  Students appreciated Cappella's use of real-life examples to clarify difficult concepts.
	Some students complained that the final exam was difficult. One student mentioned that grading seemed quite subjective. This review was based on a limited number of student comments.

section.name: The Effects of Mass Media on Stereotyping and Prejudice

values.comments:
This course asks how do qualitative social scientists study urban communities? What kinds of powerful tales can be told about urban lifestyles and social issues/conflicts in places like Philadelphia? This course will allow students to study various ethnographic treatments of urban communities in the United States, using films, articles, TV serials, and books as guides for the framing of their own independent research on the streets of Philadelphia. Students will also form production teams of two or three people, and these production teams will be responsible for (i) identifying and researching an important urban issue in contemporary Philadelphia and (ii) turning that research into a 15-30 minute radio documentary that will be broadcast on a local Philadelphia radio station, WURD 900AM. This course is intended to be a rigorous and exciting opportunity for students to tell empirically grounded stories using the voices of their subjects and the sounds of the city.
	Students felt that this course was “a wonderful idea” but complained that it “desperately is in need of more extensive planning.” Many noted the uniqueness of the course, and were excited to produce a radio documentary. However, some felt that a lot was left “for finals week” and further emphasized the need for better planning in the course.
	Only two comments were made about Professor Jackson, with one student referring to him as an “excellent instructor” and another calling him “an outstanding teacher and mentor.”
	Students enjoyed the topic of the class, but many felt that better planning was needed. The workload was described as somewhat unrealistic, especially in the latter part of the class. Many did report feeling a sense of satisfaction upon completing the final radio documentary, and the professor and TAs were described as helpful.

Communications 323 focuses on the modern media and their impact on government and politics. This course primarily covers the post-Watergate/post-Vietnam era of journalism, the past quarter century. Each week focuses on specific topics and areas of post-Watergate journalism, as well as current press coverage of national events over the prior week. This course gives students the opportunity to interact and discuss the intersection of the press, politics, and public policy with some of the leading practitioners in the field.
	Students enjoyed this class, which was praised for the “amazing array” of guest speakers as well as the “change from the more theory based courses offered at Annenberg.” However, the final paper was criticized, as students felt that it was not discussed in class until the deadline had begun to “loom large.” Students also praised the “fantastic” class discussions.  
	Professor Hunt was lauded being “caring and funny” as well as “incredibly engaging.” Students were unanimous in praise of him in general, but many complained about the final paper, which they felt he handled by “continuously putting off” in class until it was too late to ignore. Professor Hunt was also praised for his stories and wide experience in Washington.
	This course was mentioned by many commentators as their favorite at Penn; one senior felt so “fortunate” to have taken the class. Guest speakers were noted as particularly “amazing” and the class as a whole was lauded.

section.name: COMPARATIVE POL COMM: Comparative Political Communication

values.comments:
This course explores the role of communication in theories of political change and democratic development.  It addresses the questions: What are the major hypotheses about the relationship between communication and regime type?  How have our hypotheses about communication evolved over time in response to changes in prominent development theories, policy trends, technical developments, and empirical evidence? 

Overall, this course was described as being interesting and insightful to an extent. Students said the topics discussed in the course were “valuable and interesting overall but a little onerous.” Many students remarked that the final project was “annoying,” but that it was a “great learning curve.” Some also stated that the readings were very relevant to the topics they were studying in the class, but that they tended to become repetitive as the class developed. Overall, most of the students enjoyed the readings and the class discussions.

The majority of students in the class felt that Professor Moehler could do a better job of teaching in class. One student mentioned that she “was good one on one, especially in office hours.” However, some students stated that “in class she wasn’t very engaging,” and “needs to do a better job of facilitating discussion,” because they could often go off-topic, which would waste valuable class time. One student also mentioned that she was very micromanaging on the research paper.

The course is composed of a lot of reading and a final research paper. There are frequent class discussions meant to involve participation. One student mentioned that the course was “a fantastic introduction to the study of democracy within the purview of Comparative Politics.” This course is designed for Benjamin Franklin Scholars. There are no other prerequisites for this course.
